display.label: Jira
display.description: Manage Jira issues, comments, projects and users

inputs.comments: The OAuth 2.0 Authorization URL for Jira
inputs.label: Authorize URL

inputs.comments: The OAuth 2.0 Token URL for Jira
inputs.label: Token URL

inputs.comments: A space-delimited set of one or more scopes to get the user's permission to access.
inputs.default: read:project:jira read:user:jira write:issue:jira read:issue:jira read:issue-link:jira write:issue-link:jira read:issue-link-type:jira write:issue-link-type:jira read:issue.transition:jira delete:issue:jira offline_access
inputs.label: Scopes

inputs.comments: Provide a string value for the version of your Jira API request
inputs.label: Version

documentation.description:
While Jira's Cloud API has support for legacy OAuth 1.0, Prismatic only offers support for [Jira's OAuth 2.0 (3LO) flows](https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/jira/platform/oauth-2-3lo-apps/#enabling-oauth-2-0--3lo-).
If you select OAuth 2.0, you need to enable it for your app using the [Atlassian developer console](https://developer.atlassian.com/console).

Create a new "Oauth 2.0 integration" and give it a name.
Under the app details section, take note of your client Id and client secret values that were generated.
After you have saved those values, find the Authorization section and click configure on Oauth 2.0 (3LO).
There you will be prompted to enter your redirect URL, which you can find under the credentials tab in the Prismatic settings. - https<!---->://oauth2.prismatic.io/callback - as a **Redirect URL**.
Next navigate to the permissions. It is important that you remain consistent with the scopes you supply in both Jira, and your Prismatic connection.
The default scopes on a new connection in Prismatic will be as follows:
`read:project:jira`
`read:user:jira`
`write:issue:jira`
`read:issue:jira`
`read:issue-link:jira`
`write:issue-link:jira`
`read:issue-link-type:jira`
`write:issue-link-type:jira`
`read:issue.transition:jira`
`delete:issue:jira`
These scopes will provide access to the most of the actions in the Jira component, but you may have to modify the scopes in both locations (Prismatic and Atlassian Console) to meet your needs.

For more information on developing Jira applications, follow the guide [here](https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/jira/platform/oauth-2-3lo-apps/).

Next, you can configure an OAuth 2.0 connection within Prismatic.
Add a Jira step to your integration.
This will automatically create a Jira connection config variable.
Ensure the connection is of type `Jira OAuth 2.0 Connection` and enter the following details:

-   For **Client ID** and **Client Secret** enter the values that you got from the Atlassian Developer Console
-   As stated previously **Scopes** will default to the following:
    `read:project:jira`
    `read:user:jira`
    `write:issue:jira`
    `read:issue:jira`
    `read:issue-link:jira`
    `write:issue-link:jira`
    `read:issue-link-type:jira`
    `write:issue-link-type:jira`
    `read:issue.transition:jira`
    `delete:issue:jira`.
    with the addition of `offline_access` on the connection side to obtain a refresh token.
    From here you can do any [additional configuration](https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/jira/platform/scopes-for-connect-and-oauth-2-3LO-apps/#oauth-2-0-authorization-code-only-scopes) to match your use case. For example, you might assign the scopes `manage:jira-project read:jira-user` if you plan to work with Users and Projects. You will need to enable these scopes on the [Atlassian Developer Console](https://developer.atlassian.com/apps) page for your OAuth 2.0 Jira app. It is important to include `offline_access` in your scopes, or you will not be given a refresh token.
-   For **Version** enter the version of Jira you use (you likely use version **2**).


Jira API: manage:jira-configuration, manage:jira-project, write:jira-work, read:jira-work.

inputs.comments: Provide a valid username for the given jira account you want to connect.
inputs.label: Username

inputs.comments: Provide an api token to authenticate all requests with. Cloud users need to generate an API token for this value.
inputs.label: API Key

inputs.comments: Provide a string value for the URL of your Jira account.
inputs.label: Host

inputs.comments: Provide a string value for the version of your Jira API request
inputs.label: Version

documentation.description:
If you select Basic Auth and you are using Jira Cloud, you will need to supply your Jira email and an API token to the connection.
If you are on a locally hosted instance of Jira, you will need to supply your Jira email and password to the connection.
For information on generating an API token from Jira Cloud, refer to the [Atlassian docs](https://support.atlassian.com/atlassian-account/docs/manage-api-tokens-for-your-atlassian-account/).

display.label: Create Webhook
display.description: Create a webhook to send data from Jira to an instance URL

inputs.comments: Reference a flow's URL from the trigger payload
inputs.label: Webhook URL

inputs.comments: Webhook Details payload to send in this create request; must match structure of `webhooks` property for Register Dynamic Webhook endpoint: https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/jira/platform/rest/v3/api-group-webhooks/#api-rest-api-3-webhook-post
inputs.label: Webhook Details

documentation.description: Registering a [Dynamic Webhook](https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/jira/platform/rest/v3/api-group-webhooks/) requires supplying a [highly configurable payload called "Webhook Details"](https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/jira/platform/rest/v3/api-group-webhooks/#api-rest-api-3-webhook-post). It's important to configure this for all use cases as each Jira app is only permitted to create and manage one endpoint.

display.label: Raw Request
display.description: Send a raw HTTP request to Jira API

inputs.comments: Input the path only (/rest/api/3/project/recent), The base URL is already included (https://api.atlassian.com/ex/jira/<CLOUD_ID>). For example, to connect to https://api.atlassian.com/ex/jira/<CLOUD_ID>/rest/api/3/project/recent, only /rest/api/3/project/recent is entered in this field.
inputs.label: URL

inputs.comments: The HTTP method to use.
inputs.label: Method

inputs.comments: The HTTP body payload to send to the URL.
inputs.label: Data

inputs.comments: The Form Data to be sent as a multipart form upload.
inputs.label: Form Data

inputs.comments: File Data to be sent as a multipart form upload.
inputs.label: File Data

inputs.placeholder: The file name to apply to a file
inputs.comments: File names to apply to the file data inputs. Keys must match the file data keys above.
inputs.label: File Data File Names

inputs.comments: A list of query parameters to send with the request. This is the portion at the end of the URL similar to ?key1=value1&key2=value2.
inputs.label: Query Parameter

inputs.comments: A list of headers to send with the request.
inputs.label: Header

inputs.comments: The type of data you expect in the response. You can request json, text, or binary data.
inputs.label: Response Type

inputs.comments: The maximum time that a client will await a response to its request
inputs.label: Timeout

inputs.comments: Enabling this flag will log out the current request.
inputs.label: Debug Request

inputs.comments: The delay in milliseconds between retries.
inputs.label: Retry Delay (ms)

inputs.comments: If true, retries on all erroneous responses regardless of type.
inputs.label: Retry On All Errors

inputs.comments: The maximum number of retries to attempt.
inputs.label: Max Retry Count

inputs.comments: Specifies whether to use a pre-defined exponential backoff strategy for retries.
inputs.label: Use Exponential Backoff

display.label: Issue Fields
display.description: A map of a list of fields to Jira Issue Fields.

documentation.description:
[Jira](https://www.atlassian.com/software/jira) is a proprietary issue tracking product developed by Atlassian that allows bug tracking and agile project management.
This component allows you to create, update, comment on, and delete issues in a Jira project.
